--- title: "Interactivity" date: "2023-10-23" date_end: "2023-10-27" --- ## Readings ### Explorable explanations - {{< fa trophy >}} Marcel Salathé and Nicky Case, ["What Happens Next: COVID-19 Futures, Explained with Playable Situations"](https://ncase.me/covid-19/) - {{< fa arrow-up-right-from-square >}} Brett Victor, ["Explorable Explanations"](http://worrydream.com/ExplorableExplanations/) - {{< fa trophy >}} Look at [some of the explorable explorations here](https://explorabl.es/) - {{< fa arrow-up-right-from-square >}} Dragicevic, Jansen, Sarma, Kay, and Chevalier, ["Explorable Multiverse Analyses"](https://explorablemultiverse.github.io/). Use Chrome, open Example 1, scroll to page 2, and click on some of the blue text to change the results of the paper *within the paper itself*. This is magical. R Markdown can't quite get *this* interactive in real-time, but you can knit different versions of a document with slightly different parameters and options. ### Dashboards - {{< fa arrow-up-right-from-square >}} Look at [some of these examples of Shiny apps](https://shiny.rstudio.com/gallery/) - {{< fa arrow-up-right-from-square >}} Stephanie Evergreen, ["How a Dashboard Changes the Conversation"](https://stephanieevergreen.com/dashboard-conversation/) - {{< fa arrow-up-right-from-square >}} Stephanie Evergreen, ["The Problem with Dashboards (and a Solution)"](https://stephanieevergreen.com/problem-with-dashboards/) - {{< fa arrow-up-right-from-square >}} Stephen Few, ["2012 Perceptual Edge Dashboard Design Competition: A Solution of My Own"](https://www.stephen-few.com/blog/2013/01/08/2012-perceptual-edge-dashboard-design-competition-a-solution-of-my-own/) - {{< fa file-pdf >}} Skim through Stephen Few's [presentation on Information Dashboard Design](http://blogs.ischool.berkeley.edu/i247s12/files/2012/01/Dashboard-Design-Overview-Presentation.pdf) - {{< fa brands google >}} Google "dashboard design" and skim through some of the thousands of articles about what makes a good (and bad) dashboard ### Possible questions to reflect on ::: {.callout-warning} #### This is not a required list! Remember, you don't need to answer all of these—or even any of them! These are just here to help guide your thinking. **Write about whatever you want.** ::: - How helpful (or unhelpful) are explorable explanations? - Have you seen examples of good dashboards before this class? Bad dashboards? What makes them good or bad? ## Slides The slides for this week's lesson are available online as an HTML file.
